Hi all!

I was gone for a while, but before a day or so I had some spare ti=
me to continue my research about automated substrate evolution. 

My latest=
 research so far ended up with a system capable of approximating any spatia=
l CPPN picture with a developing mesh based on the Growing Neural Gas algor=
ithm. While this worked well and could be used for evolving substrate confi=
gurations right away, there was still a problem about deciding the right nu=
mber of nodes for particular individuals. With GNG, it is more like a probl=
em of deciding when to stop development or approximation of the CPPN pictur=
e. 

When we discussed the issue some time ago, I had the idea that CPPN co=
mplexity can be directly linked to substrate density. More complex CPPN =3D=
 more dense substrate. This seems like a solution but it I think it is actu=
ally a bad idea. A CPPN containing many nodes and links does not always pro=
duce a complex pattern in space. It can be an entirely white or black pictu=
re, due to genetic defects. Plus, it is not sure that the problem requires =
that many nodes to be solved - the CPPN may have enormous complexity but pr=
oducing a simple well-shaped picture that solves it. 

So what I think now =
is, that substrate density should be related to fitness instead. How exactl=
y? Well here is my idea. 

All individuals start with a minimal number of n=
odes in the substrate, say 50. There will be a mutation increasing the numb=
er of nodes with about 0%-10% or decreasing with 0%-10%. The mutation rate =
will vary across species. Species that are stagnating for too long time wil=
l have the probability of this mutation increased - because they may just l=
ack the number of nodes to solve the problem. Or have too many nodes. 

You=
 know, there is a problem with having the number of nodes increasing and th=
is is the over saturation of the sigmoid. Increasing the density with 2x wi=
ll have very big impact if the weights are not altered, especially in case =
recurrence is present. How can we cope with that? 

I don't have any experi=
mental data yet, I am too busy programming some bullshit but please tell me=
 if this ideas make sense to you. 

Peter
